Articles.Content: I have taken to wondering. Watching a documentary, I discovered that the Apollo 13 LEM used its engine to "speed up its orbit." This is something that has always bothered me about orbital mechanics - how was their trajectory changed to shave a full nine hours off their return time? Was the reentry steeper and hotter? How did the return trajectory match up with the other Apollo missions?

Keep your Periapsis roughly the same, but burn towards a direction that would throw you out of Earth's orbit if there was no atmosphere. Basically, Apollo 13 probably made their Apoapsis much higher than what it used to be.

Interesting question.

All I could find out is this:

They had to re-establish their free return trajectory by burning the LM engines

This trajectory gave them a moon periapsis of 100km higher than "normal" (not sure if higher than free return or just higher than mission plan)

The "speed up the orbit" burn is called a PC+2 burn, meaning its done 2 hours after lunar periapsis. Not sure what that means yet.

The reentry was a bit unusual but not sure how unusual

The reentry was longer than expected.

This has nothing to do with the burn tough.
Though the speed up its orbits still the return was slower than it was expected.
